image.altText: An old looking hospital

items.synopsis: The incidents occurred when the patient, identified only as "Mr J", was admitted to the Women's and Children's Hospital's mental health ward in August 2021, and breached basic restraint and seclusion rules, a report released today has found.

title.children: Young patient was kept secluded for hours, restrained face down at Adelaide children's hospital

image.altText: An image of a woman in her kitchen.

items.synopsis: The state opposition and a business group say the Labor government's budget doesn't address rising expenses for households and businesses, with one Adelaide carer welcoming relief measures but describing them as "band-aid at the best".

title.children: SA budget a 'slap in the face' for the average household, opposition says

image.altText: Police lights and a sign sitting on top of a police car

items.synopsis: Two men from New South Wales will face court today charged with money laundering after a traffic stop on South Australia's Eyre Highway allegedly led to the discovery of more than $2 million in cash stashed in three bags.

title.children: Bags containing $2 million in cash uncovered during SA truck stop, police say

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: Peter Dutton says he was made aware of another allegation against Senator David Van and that the senator should quit parliament, following claims made by Senator Lidia Thorpe and former senator Amanda Stoker in recent days.

title.children: Peter Dutton says Senator David Van should quit parliament, after another allegation raised with him

image.altText: Kiwi crossing in New Zealand

items.synopsis: New Zealand was among the first developed economies to start increasing interest rates, and it is yet to see inflation in its target zone. This is how the country compares to Australia.

title.children: New Zealand is officially in a recession. These charts show how Australia compares

image.altText: Patrick Dangerfield pumps his fist in celebration

items.synopsis: Geelong confirms star midfielder Patrick Dangerfield played on with a cracked rib and partially collapsed lung in the club's loss to the Power.

title.children: Cats confirm Patrick Dangerfield played on with partially collapsed lung

image.altText: Two men wearing suits and smiling stand side by side in front of a glass window

items.synopsis: The South Australian Labor government has sought to address housing affordability woes and skyrocketing cost-of-living pressures in its second budget.

title.children: Stamp duty relief and billions poured into hospitals in South Australian budget

image.altText: A man smiles.

items.synopsis: The yachtsman, winemaker and businessman — who was part of the team that wrested the America's Cup from the United States — dies in Adelaide aged 90.

title.children: Champion yachtsman and wine boss Sir James Hardy dies aged 90

image.altText: A man wears khaki work wear, a hat and sunglasses. He stands in a green field of grain plants, clouds are behind him

items.synopsis: Pinnaroo farmer Wade Nickolls says bigger farms need more employees to operate which can then bring new people to the region. But the trick is how to attract them.

title.children: Farms are getting bigger but suffer from fewer new farmers

image.altText: Chief Justice Susan Kiefel.

items.synopsis: The first woman to be the chief justice of the High Court, Susan Kiefel announces her early retirement from the highest court in the land.

title.children: Trailblazing justice Susan Kiefel to retire early from the High Court

image.altText: LIz Indrans

items.synopsis: A report by Swinburne University of Technology found 10 companies that trialled a four-day work week continued it after a pilot, with four organisations adopting the change permanently.

title.children: These employers have introduced four-day work weeks and 'can't think of a downside'

image.altText: Ice in the ocean

items.synopsis: This year has already produced record high ocean temperatures, record low Antarctic sea ice, and global air temperatures well above average all year.

title.children: Sudden surge of record high temperatures could propel 2023 as warmest year on record

image.altText: Screenshot from a video showing a police car and people holding up a tarp by the road

items.synopsis: Video from the scene showed firefighters spraying water on a burning white vehicle that was in a ditch to the side of the road.

title.children: At least 15 people dead in Canada as truck hits bus carrying elderly people

image.altText: Indigenous woman Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks to a forum, with and Indegenous elder and child flanked either side.

items.synopsis: With a referendum on the Voice to Parliament approaching in the second half of the year, there's one myth about the proposed body which refuses to die, despite repeated debunking.

title.children: This myth about the Voice pushed by No campaigners including Jacinta Nampijinpa Price refuses to die

image.altText: a photo of a phone that shows 'SOS"

items.synopsis: Claire Harrison says she's still recovering from losing her identity and tens of thousands of dollars by mobile porting fraud, where scammers port your mobile number to another device.

title.children: 'Terrifying' phone porting scam stealing millions but cybersecurity experts say it's unavoidable

image.altText: A pair of smiling newlyweds at their reception.

items.synopsis: Madison Tougher, who married Steven Tougher weeks before his alleged murder, has welcomed their daughter into the world, the NSW Ambulance service has announced.

title.children: 'Great joy out of great sadness' as slain paramedic's wife gives birth to their baby girl

image.altText: A mug shot of a man

items.synopsis: He's already serving three life sentences after confessing to a trio of underworld murders. Now Abuzar Sultani has been sentenced for his role in the death of a teenager in Sydney 10 years ago.

title.children: Judge describes hit man's rehabilitation as 'pointless exercise' as he jails him for fourth Sydney murder

image.altText: two men close up

items.synopsis: The independent politician, who is suing the NSW One Nation leader for defamation, says his offensive tweet was seen by 6,171 people on Twitter.

title.children: Mark Latham's tweet at centre of defamation storm seen by 6,000 people, court documents allege

image.altText: Man wearing a black top with red stripe, standing outside.

items.synopsis: Amid a shift away from opioids — with prescriptions dropping 30 per cent between 2016 and 2021 — chronic pain sufferers like Daniel King are experiencing acute distress.

title.children: 'It's soul destroying': A shift away from opioid prescriptions is causing distress for people with chronic pain

image.altText: Bunch of flowers with a note a attached.

items.synopsis: A fundraiser to help those affected by the fatal bus crash in the NSW Hunter Valley raises an astonishing amount of money, as hundreds gather for a community vigil at the crash site.

title.children: More than $240k donated to Hunter Valley wedding bus crash victims and their families

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it is pushing Russian forces back in places along the southern and eastern frontlines, while Moscow announces plans for elections in occupied areas in its latest bid to signal it is in control.

title.children: Drone footage reveals scale of Russian destruction in Bakhmut as Ukraine presses counteroffensive

image.altText: Joko Widodo sitting in front of a microphone

items.synopsis: Treasury staff must register all gifts received. Those over $100 go on the internet. Those below that value have been uncovered in FOI documents obtained by the ABC.

title.children: Treasury gets the chocolates as gift registry exposed

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: AGL's bottom line is set to get a big boost while consumers are hit with rising energy bills. And local shares are trading higher today, after a Wall Street rally. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: AGL shares soar as energy giant set to double profits, ASX climbs and Europe lifts rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Sales of new homes increased by 9.4 per cent in May, but purchases are still 40 per cent lower than the year before and 25 per cent down on pre-pandemic levels. HIA Senior Economist Tom Devitt said new home sales remain at "depressed levels." "This indicates that the slowdown in home building that is underway will continue for at least the next year," Mr Devitt said. “The most significant contraction in sales is in New South Wales where customers are more sensitive to rises in the cash rate. “Cancellations also remain elevated at a rate of 25 per cent in the last quarter. This means, for every four new projects a builder is recording, a previous project is being cancelled. “The RBA’s rate increases will continue to hold down new sales and cause further cancellations as finance becomes unobtainable for an increasing number of buyers. “The significant increase in the cost of land and construction across all jurisdictions over the past two years is compounding the impact of higher interest rates. " Mr Devitt also blamed the National Construction Code which came into effect this year (which means houses need to be more energy efficient) for driving up construction costs and dampening demand. “This combination of factors will see home building continuing to contract for at least the next 12 months to its lowest level in more than a decade,” Mr Devitt said. He said sales of new homes in the three months to May 2023 compared to the same time last year are still down in most large states, led by New South Wales (-63.6 per cent), and followed by Queensland (-52.9 per cent), Victoria (-46.6 per cent) and South Australia (-29.5 per cent). Western Australia saw the only increase over the year, up by 19.4 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HIA says housing construction to fall to lowest levels in a decade

children.content: Sales of new homes increased by 9.4 per cent in May, but purchases are still 40 per cent lower than the year before and 25 per cent down on pre-pandemic levels.
HIA Senior Economist Tom Devitt said new home sales remain at "depressed levels."
"This indicates that the slowdown in home building that is underway will continue for at least the next year," Mr Devitt said.
“The most significant contraction in sales is in New South Wales where customers are more sensitive to rises in the cash rate.
“Cancellations also remain elevated at a rate of 25 per cent in the last quarter. This means, for every four new projects a builder is recording, a previous project is being cancelled.
“The RBA’s rate increases will continue to hold down new sales and cause further cancellations as finance becomes unobtainable for an increasing number of buyers.
“The significant increase in the cost of land and construction across all jurisdictions over the past two years is compounding the impact of higher interest rates. "
Mr Devitt also blamed the National Construction Code which came into effect this year (which means houses need to be more energy efficient) for driving up construction costs and dampening demand.
“This combination of factors will see home building continuing to contract for at least the next 12 months to its lowest level in more than a decade,” Mr Devitt said.

He said sales of new homes in the three months to May 2023 compared to the same time last year are still down in most large states, led by New South Wales (-63.6 per cent), and followed by Queensland (-52.9 per cent), Victoria (-46.6 per cent) and South Australia (-29.5 per cent).
Western Australia saw the only increase over the year, up by 19.4 per cent.
Private new house sales
(HIA )

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Casino operator Crown has been fined $20 million for failing to pay enough tax. The Victorian Gambling and Casino Control Commission (VGCCC) has also taken disciplinary action against Crown Melbourne. The Royal Commission into the Casino Operator and Licence found that Crown claimed tax deductions by including the costs of certain promotional activities as amounts paid out as winnings. Crown deliberately concealed the deductions from the VGCCC’s predecessor, the Victorian Commission for Gambling and Liquor Regulation. Casino operator Crown has been fined $20 million for failing to pay enough tax. The Royal Commission into the Casino Operator and Licence found that Crown claimed tax deductions by including the costs of certain promotional activities as amounts paid out as winnings. Crown deliberately concealed the deductions from the VGCCC’s predecessor, the Victorian Commission for Gambling and Liquor Regulation. Crown has been forced to pay $61.5 million to the Victorian government for the unpaid casino tax of about $37.4 million and penalty interest of about $24.1 million. “Crown and other gaming licensees have important obligations to pay gaming taxes to the State. Not only did Crown breach its obligations by claiming tax deductions to which it was not entitled, Crown also made significant efforts at concealment,” VGCC Chairperson Fran Thorn said. "The VGCCC will not tolerate this behaviour. We expect licensees to comply with their tax obligations and to be transparent in their dealings with us. "We have today imposed a significant fine of $20 million on Crown to send a clear message that this type of conduct will be met with strong disciplinary action. "This fine also sends an important message to other gambling operators about the importance of complying with their obligations to pay gambling taxes and the need for frank and open dealings with the regulator.” Crown's been fined $250 million by the VGCC.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Crown fined $20 million for dodging tax

children.content: Casino operator Crown has been fined $20 million for failing to pay enough tax.
The Victorian Gambling and Casino Control Commission (VGCCC) has also taken disciplinary action against Crown Melbourne.
The Royal Commission into the Casino Operator and Licence found that Crown claimed tax deductions by including the costs of certain promotional activities as amounts paid out as winnings.
Crown deliberately concealed the deductions from the VGCCC’s predecessor, the Victorian Commission for Gambling and Liquor Regulation.
Casino operator Crown has been fined $20 million for failing to pay enough tax.
The Royal Commission into the Casino Operator and Licence found that Crown claimed tax deductions by including the costs of certain promotional activities as amounts paid out as winnings.
Crown deliberately concealed the deductions from the VGCCC’s predecessor, the Victorian Commission for Gambling and Liquor Regulation.
Crown has been forced to pay $61.5 million to the Victorian government for the unpaid casino tax of about $37.4 million and penalty interest of about $24.1 million.

“Crown and other gaming licensees have important obligations to pay gaming taxes to the State. Not only did Crown breach its obligations by claiming tax deductions to which it was not entitled, Crown also made significant efforts at concealment,” VGCC Chairperson Fran Thorn said.
"The VGCCC will not tolerate this behaviour. We expect licensees to comply with their tax obligations and to be transparent in their dealings with us.
"We have today imposed a significant fine of $20 million on Crown to send a clear message that this type of conduct will be met with strong disciplinary action.

"This fine also sends an important message to other gambling operators about the importance of complying with their obligations to pay gambling taxes and the need for frank and open dealings with the regulator.”
Crown's been fined $250 million by the VGCC.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Creditors owed money by collapsed builder Porter Davis Homes are unlikely to get any of the $71 million owed, according to a report from liquidators Grant Thornton. The findings of the liquidators mean sub-contractors and other unsecured creditors won't get the money they're owed, because most of the $147.2 million are unlikely to be recovered. "Please note, at this stage, it appears unlikely that sufficient funds will be recovered in the liquidations to  enable a dividend to be paid to ordinary unsecured creditors," the report said. "This would require all amounts owing to  secured creditors, and priority employee creditors, to be paid in full prior to any distribution to ordinary  unsecured creditors. "Further updates regarding the progress of the liquidation and the likelihood of any  dividends will be communicated in future reports." Grant Thornton said customers who signed contracts at the pre-site stage of their builds might be able to claim a refund of their deposit under state warranty or compensation schemes, to mitigate losses. However, the ABC has reported Porter Davis customers who s igned tender agreements are ineligible for the Victorian government compensation scheme. However, the liquidators said the Commonwealth Bank is expected to get back most of the $33 million it's owed. "At this stage, we anticipate the sufficient recoveries will be made in the liquidators to discharge CBA's in full," the report said. The liquidators' preliminary findings are that there is no compelling evidence Porter Davis companies were insolvent before February 2023. The report also noted directors could have protection from insolvency claims after February using a safe harbour defence. “Our investigations are ongoing in this regard,” the report said. Porter Davis collapsed in March, with an estimated 1,700 unfinished homes reported to be caught up in the collapse. The construction company has since made more than 400 staff redundant and has ceased work on building sites across Victoria and Queensland. The next meeting of creditors will be in Melbourne on June 28.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Porter Davis sub-contractors unlikely to get a cent

children.content: Creditors owed money by collapsed builder Porter Davis Homes are unlikely to get any of the $71 million owed, according to a report from liquidators Grant Thornton.
The findings of the liquidators mean sub-contractors and other unsecured creditors won't get the money they're owed, because most of the $147.2 million are unlikely to be recovered.
"Please note, at this stage, it appears unlikely that sufficient funds will be recovered in the liquidations to  enable a dividend to be paid to ordinary unsecured creditors," the report said.
"This would require all amounts owing to  secured creditors, and priority employee creditors, to be paid in full prior to any distribution to ordinary  unsecured creditors.
"Further updates regarding the progress of the liquidation and the likelihood of any  dividends will be communicated in future reports."

Grant Thornton said customers who signed contracts at the pre-site stage of their builds might be able to claim a refund of their deposit under state warranty or compensation schemes, to mitigate losses.
However, the ABC has reported Porter Davis customers who s
igned tender agreements are ineligible for the Victorian government compensation scheme.
However, the liquidators said the Commonwealth Bank is expected to get back most of the $33 million it's owed.
"At this stage, we anticipate the sufficient recoveries will be made in the liquidators to discharge CBA's in full," the report said.
The liquidators' preliminary findings are that there is no compelling evidence Porter Davis companies were insolvent before February 2023.
The report also noted directors could have protection from insolvency claims after February using a safe harbour defence.
“Our investigations are ongoing in this regard,” the report said.
Porter Davis collapsed in March, with an estimated 1,700
unfinished homes reported to be caught up in the collapse.
The construction company has since made more than 400 staff redundant and has ceased work on building sites across Victoria and Queensland.
The next meeting of creditors will be in Melbourne on June 28.

image.altText: A man is lowered into a mine shaft

items.synopsis: Pictures document a painstaking search for clues in WA's remote Mid-West region, as police return to the century-old mineshaft where the body of an amateur prospector was found eight years ago.

title.children: Police dig up mine shaft in hope of solving baffling WA outback murder mystery

image.altText: Picture of a sign saying caution with an open pit coal mine and power station in the background

items.synopsis: A supposed exemplar of energy security and prescience just last year, Western Australia is now facing calls for a shake-up of its policies amid soaring prices and supply strains.

title.children: Australia's energy woes shift west as state's power and gas prices head skywards

image.altText: A woman looks to the sky as she holds the end wall of a swimming pool.

items.synopsis: Mollie O'Callaghan's meteoric rise in Australian swimming continues, as Queenslanders dominate the pool in Melbourne.

title.children: O'Callaghan 'over the moon' after pipping Titmus, as Queenslanders dominate Aussie swimming trials

image.altText: A woman hits a cricket ball.

items.synopsis: Australia's search for a new Test opening pairing appears to end as Beth Mooney dominates the England A attack in Leicester.

title.children: Ashes opening pairing firms for Australia as Beth Mooney dominates in warm up clash

image.altText: Argentina's Lionel Messi shoots the ball at the goal.

title.children: Messi makes history again as Argentina defeats Socceroos

image.altText: An aerial photo shows an overcrowded boat on a blue sea.

items.synopsis: As authorities continue to look for the hundreds of missing passengers, nine survivors accused of being part of the smuggling ring behind the tragedy are arrested.

image.altText: A group of women run around a track.

items.synopsis: Aussie runners push their global rivals at the Bislett Games, and claim Australian records with strong performances in Oslo.

title.children: Jess Hull and Olli Hoare power to Australian records at the Bislett Games in Oslo

image.altText: A court sketch illustration shows a middle-aged white male judge questioning a young white man with short hair.

title.children: Man accused of leaking US military secrets on Discord indicted by grand jury

image.altText: A prison mugshot of Duane Owen in an orange jumpsuit

items.synopsis: One of Florida's longest-held death row inmates, Owen was 23 at the time of the attacks and 62 when he was executed.

title.children: US man executed over 1984 killings of teenage babysitter and mother-of-two

image.altText: An aerial shot of the Chandler Indoor Sports Centre, with tiles of Olympic sports bordering the picture

items.synopsis: Everyone's talking about the Gabba, but more than a dozen Queensland suburbs are included in the 2032 master plan.

title.children: Here are the 16 locations set for a makeover ahead of the 2032 Olympics

image.altText: A woman in a white shirt with short brown hair in a still from a movie

items.synopsis: Dial of Destiny is the fifth and final instalment in the Indiana Jones franchise, which started with 1981’s Raiders of the Lost Ark.

title.children: 'He's as mad as a box of squirrels': Behind the scenes of the final Indiana Jones adventure

image.altText: Brisbane Lions players walk out at the MCG

items.synopsis: Brisbane has lost 12 games in row at the MCG during the home-and-away season, but that's not the worst run of any one team at any one ground in AFL/VFL history.

title.children: The Lions are facing an MCG hoodoo — but how does that compare to the worst streaks in history?
